turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: They found it and didn't justify it.
So that -- but they didn't weigh it.
They took it into account and found that it would not support the award of the certificate.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All I'm suggesting is the inferior and superior were not written into the statute.

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It's not written into it.

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.
I recognize that.
But on the other hand, conservation is a consideration that this Court has recognized and the Commission has and it's tried to weigh these things.
Now, what the basic issue in this case is that they claimed, they would have a right to buy this gas in Texas and flare it, just let it go out in the air and burn it or just let it go in New York.
And the Commission has no power, except to say whether they'll permit it to be transported regardless of that use.

And the basic issue of the Government -- the Federal Power Commission is that pubic convenience and necessity is such that and has always been conceded to include the various considerations that would make up that and they can deny the transportation even though the purchase is valid and the use would be valid but they don't have to permit transportation that is not in the public convenience and necessity for that kind of use.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Isn't it a fact though that the fact that the purchase was not regulable was an important consideration in denying the certificate?

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: The fact that -- no, the fact that the effect of the purchase on the whole industry was such that it would damage the interest of the consumer was what was the denial of the case.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But all none -- but all non principle cases, non-resalable sale has some effect on the industry.

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.
But they don't all have this damaging effect.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, this specific case or that the general attitude of looking a sketch at large non-regulable purchases in the field that the Commission was ruled by.

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: I think it was be the effect in this particular case plus the fact that this is demonstrated by the record to be something that Transco has held out.
They said to every purchaser they had, but they finally changed what we couldn't hold it out to little purchasers, they couldn't do it.
But they held it out to everyone in their big purchasers if you -- if Con Edison gets it, then the rest of you get the same thing.
And that would destroy the whole gas industry that was to protect the little consumers throughout this country.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well nobody -- well there's no pollution problem, never mind whether it's valid in this case or not.

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Where there's no pollution problem, the pollution blame can't be made.

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well but they used, as I pointed out, case after case here, where they're trying to use it in regard to their burrs, they're using it -- they want to use it in regard to their compressors.
They want to take it all the way around to California through Mexico, to have it not regulated by the Federal Power Commission.

Millions and millions of thousand cubic feet of gas, they're all shown here that these various considerations so that I don't see how the Federal Power Commission could disregard these other potential cases right before their eyes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Suppose they made a general rule that no large scale industrial purchasers in the field for non-resale will be allowed.
They couldn't regulate that.

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: No, I don't -- I don't claim to have any such power.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But they could say, we'll give no certificate to, what did they call it, carrier to transport that which you legally bought, they could do that?

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: I think so, because I think that they have to apply the public convenience and necessity and if they don't find that affirmatively required, they do not grant it, and here, the fact that this would be damaging to the whole industry and the protection of the consumer and also this business of conservation is not any mere bug of the lure or something that's threatened.

When you think of how the gas passed the reserves that this country have gone down, as far as the estimate is concerned, so that they're talking now in terms of 20 some years in exhaustion, rather than 30 some years.
It's a real consideration, and the Commission says that it has the power to consider all of those elements.
Now, this wasn't a new proposition.

There were 20 years of regulation under the term, public convenience and necessity, prior to the Natural Gas Act and under the ICC and, of course, this Court's recognized that that was the source of that term.

And when you took public convenience and necessity in case after case, in regard to the ICC, you didn't say, why if there can be -- if you can find the consideration that weather or not, this line has got the money and has got the route and whether or not, there's somewhat else competing with it, that those are the only things you can look at about public convenience and necessity.
This Court has said you can look at the whole thing, the whole fabric, to see what it does for the people of this country in the area that's applied for.
And in that, you take all of these considerations to protect the top, the real purpose of the Act which is to protect consumers.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't -- you may recall, I do not recall any comparable institute in the field of -- under the Interstate Commerce Act whereby, the certificating power was used in order to prevent an otherwise congressionally authorize power to block an otherwise specifically authorized congressional, non-regulatable power, I mean, purchase not for resale.

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: Of course, I don't --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't think, they're wrong, all I am saying is the situation.

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: I don't concede that's the case here.
I say --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, because they -- they said, the purchase by Con Edison is non-resalable, isn't it?

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, nobody's complaining about it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well I know.

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: They can buy as much as they wanted.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What I'm saying is what you're arguing here is that the convenience and necessity power of the Commission can be utilized in order not to reference to itself, but primarily and predominantly isn't just made so clear.
They cleared that moments ago, predominantly, to prevent an exercise of power, which Congress has authorized people to exercise.

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: No, Mr. Justice Frankfurter, I think this is different, because I think this particular facility, when you certificate a carrier, you're talking about a capacity of the pipeline, and pipelines don't have indefinite or unlimited capacity.
They are dependent upon their capital power, their power to borrow the money, and the extent of their ability to build such pipelines.
And they can only build so much with any capital structure.
So that you're talking about, shall this portion of the pipeline be used, preempted, dedicated anywhere you want to use for it, for the purpose of this kind.
Is it in the public convenience and necessity interest?
And I think that's where -- that's the test.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But I'm accepting your argument that this would be adverse to the natural gas industry, but that which is adverse specifically allowed by Congress namely, to purchase not for resale.

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: And I concede that the purchase is allowed and they can purchase and nobody is saying they can't.
But I say there is no place that Congress said that if it isn't in the public convenience and necessity, they have a right to transport.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: They can purchase but they -- they have the legal right to purchase, but they can't make that right effective.

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well they can make it effective for many things but they can't make effective, as far as being transported, because Congress said that has to be subject to the public convenience and necessity.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Your time's up but I'd like to ask just one question.

In regulating sale or resale, issuing certificates of convenience and necessity, has the Commission heretofore taken into consideration the elements that it has taken into consideration here in determining the certificate necessity for transportation?

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes, in regard to the end use, it has in the number of cases.
There are some --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What I mean particularly is that it said, some instances that you're going to use to boiler for industry and not enough for homes?

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes.
They have in this way, they have said where they applied for gas for boiler use, you can have that gas for boiler use, you can have it for starting the boiler or for the preliminary heating up.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What was the basis for that?

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: They took the position that they had a right to control the conservation aspects of end use.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean the end use?

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So as to a certain extent of bring about an apportionment for certain use for it.

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well, they were trying --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's what I gather, you're arguing here --

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- by domestic use of another.
Has that been utilized in our exercise of the Commission's power generally, by it does have power regularly.

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: I'm advised that it has and as far as we've set out in the brief in detail, the cases and I think they show that they have tried to exercise it in that manner.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Can you set out in next (Inaudible) that have been approved?

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: Well I can answer that Mr. Justice Clark in this way that boiler fuel user contracts have been set out.
We don't -- I don't know of any just like X-20.
This is a peculiar animal, not the way it's come up.
But the comparable boiler use cases have been set out.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: For direct purchase?

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: Yes -- No, the only direct purchase that I know of --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The Florida case.

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: -- would be the Florida case.
The others are I think, more of the other kind.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Purchase of the pipeline.

turn.speaker: james_lee_rankin
turn.label: Mr. James Lee Rankin
turn.text: But there maybe some direct purchases too.
They're all -- we tried to deal with all.
